--- John Arrowwood <jarrowwx@...> wrote:
> Assuming that the goal is for the network XML to be
> transmitted to someone 
> for evaluation, it might be useful to have an
> experiment ID, a generation 
> ID, and an organism ID.  That way, when returning
> the evaluation results, it 
> can return it to a single point of contact that then
> knows where to put 
> them.  Then, it won't be necessary for the server to
> maintain a list of who 
> took what and then run the risk of getting things
> confused.

Thanks for the input.

The way we're currently doing our runs and generating
XML, all the information you're talking about is
stored in the run XML.  I would think the way it would
work, if someone wanted to share an evolved population
with someone else, is that they could zip up all the
XML files for individuals (e.g. network XML)...and
these could include simply the individuals from the
final generation, or all individuals from the entire
run...and a single run XML doc, which serves as an
index to all the individuals, contains all the
parameters, etc.

Derek
